subtopics.par: A mutual fund is a collection of specially chosen stocks, typically managed by a portfolio manager. They decide what they think is going to go up, and you invest in their ability to analyze. It's called a mutual fund because the money that the portfolio manager uses is an aggregation of all the funds given to them by their investors.

list: Active
Costs roughly 1% of the total assets
The manager is a real person who (hopefully) adds value to your investment
Passive (a.k.a. Index Funds)
Costs roughly .02-.2% of the total assets
The manager might be electronic, meaning they donâ€™t add any real value
Vanguard is the largest mutual fund company, and it's known for its passive investing

subtopics.par: The objective of mutual funds is to beat the market return of roughly 8%.
list: Only 10 - 15 % of mutual funds do this consistently
Only choose those who have been successful over a long period of time (3,5,10,15 year ranges)

subtopics.par: Mutual Funds are required to give you their Capital Gains Distribution - the sum of all the money they made from active trading. This seems like a good thing, but it really ends up with you not making as much money
list: First, think about the when you sell a stock vs. hold a stock for longer
Realized Gains - Profit that has been taken from buying and selling a stock
Unrealized Gains - you have the stock, but have not sold it yet
You must pay taxes on the following components of realized gains as taxable income (it is a permanent loss)
Long term capital gains - gains from the portion of the mutual fund that been held for more than 1 year
Short term capital gains - gains from the portion of the mutual fund made this year
Dividends - gains from dividend
This is exacerbated by active mutual funds because they keep on buying and selling rather than letting it grow over the long term.
Passive mutual funds have a MUCH MUCH lower Capital Gains Distribution
If you own a stock yourself, you only have to pay taxes on dividend
But in a mutual fund you pay taxes on the 3 components of capital gains distribution every year
For long term stocks, even if you are reinvesting the remaining portion of the CGD, you are missing out on the potential gains from the part you were forced to pay in taxes every year
Account for this when you are evaluating a mutual fund (e.g. 9% return is decreased because they keep on giving you back the CGD every year

subtopics.par: Hedge Funds are not mutual funds, but they are the same in concept. To hedge means to protect, so their goal is to NOT lose money.
list: Meant for accredited investors - there is a certain financial standard which you must meet (high net worth)
Costs about 2% upfront and they take 20% of the profits
They use specific strategies to decrease loss
They buy puts to insure themselves if the market goes down, but then they invest very aggressively
